Award.AwardTitle: Planning IUCRC Virginia Tech: Center for Cyber-Physical Systems for the Hospital Operating Room (CyBHOR)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The U.S. alone spent $2.6 trillion on healthcare in 2014. This number is likely to increase over the next two decades as Baby Boomers, numbering 76 million, will retire, including many who work in medical professions. This planning grant will lay the foundation to establish a site of the Cyber-physical systems for the Hospital Operating Room (CyBHOR) Industry University Cooperative Research Center at Virginia Tech (VT). As part of this proposed site, the researchers seek to develop healthcare and surgical technologies for our most vulnerable populations: children and older adults. The site will complement existing sites at Houston Methodist and the University of Florida.

Virginia Tech will use this planning grant to refine the vision for the new site in order to address growing biomedical needs complementary to the mission of CyBHOR. To achieve this, an organizational meeting will be held in the Washington, DC area with prospective industry members, secure financial commitments from industry partners, and select initial projects. The planning grant will allow the recruitment and input from multiple industrial partners to investigate six medical device research projects. Initial proposed research projects address areas ranging from training the next generation of healthcare workers via humanoid patient simulation, to treating both pediatric and geriatric surgical and healthcare needs with real-time tissue property monitoring. These projects will be refined with industry partners for the site's initial research efforts that will lead to increased innovation and competitiveness of U.S. industry, specifically providers of healthcare products.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided financial support to host an organizational meeting in the Washington, DC area for prospective partners to select initial projects for inclusion in our full grant proposal to NSF for the establishment of the proposed Cyber-physical systems for the Hospital Operating Room (CyBHOR)center at Virginia Tech. A well-attended planning meeting was held on August 14 – 15, 2018 in Arlington, VA with representatives from 7 potential members (including 2 startup companies), 6 strategic partners (including the FDA, NIH, Children’s Hospital, Commonwealth Care), 10 Virginia Tech (VT) researchers, the existing CyBHOR site Directors, and the VT business engagement office (LINK). The feedback from the group was encouraging and constructive. There was a sense of camaraderie amongst the participants at the meeting and a desire to facilitate these efforts at Virginia Tech. With that said, there was some concern about working with the other industry partners at the other institutions although they were not present. However, our mission and vision for transforming medical device development and treatments with the inclusion of our Veterinary College were well received. The biggest feedback centered around the composition of the proposed site. Our emphasis on training the next generation of medical workers and industrial scientists/engineers was of particular interest to our potential members. While this was included in our original proposal, there has been significant input on how to shape the training experiences to have maximum impact for our members and the possibility of requiring a training experience within proposed projects. We have ongoing conversations with Intuitive Surgical and Veterans Administration of Virginia to include a training exchange between VT students and the two members to expand our education component of the new Center node.


Last Modified: 04/08/2019
Modified by: Rafael V Davalos

The feedback from the group was encouraging and constructive. There was a sense of camaraderie amongst the participants at the meeting and a desire to facilitate these efforts at Virginia Tech.
